Author: Mylo#8306
Content: Look inside your (fiat) wallet.   Each note and coin is a "UTXO".  UTXO is non-divisible amount, just like a 20 dollar note.  If you buy something for $10.  you give your $20, and get $10 change, you don't rip your $20 in half.   instead of physical notes with fixed values.  our notes (UTXO) can be any previous amount used for change, ready to be spent again.  hope that helps a bit.  give it another read, slowly.  there's vids on youtube to explain some of these concepts in more real world terms üòÉ

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @jl777c I think you will find this wiki page a succinct way to see if incompatible changes are coming in via BTC 0.17, which could effect notaries trying to use the latest btc. There are a few backward incompat changes, of course: https://github.com/bitcoin-core/bitcoin-devwiki/wiki/0.17.0-Release-notes#low-level-rpc-changes

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: also, txindexes are now much friendlier in btc 0.17, you can incrementally build them up and use partially synced chains that didn't have txindex: https://github.com/bitcoin-core/bitcoin-devwiki/wiki/0.17.0-Release-notes#transaction-index-changes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it doesnt seem to be breaking changes for what we are using

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: sounds good

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but no sense to update BTC

Author: Meyse#0952
Content: when i run this on windows, it gives a JSON error, any idea why that is? komodo-cli.exe signrawtransaction "hexstring" ([{"txid":"the_txid","vout":1,"scriptPubKey":"bladiebla","redeemScript":"37898ew7er98adjf"}] ["privatekey"])

Author: Meyse#0952
Content: we cant get it to work, help would be appreciated

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: without the exact cli, impossible to spot any syntax error. dont need the privkey, but it seems you need to escape the arrays

Author: bartwr#6773
Content:
Like this?

`komodo-cli.exe signrawtransaction "hexstring" ([{\"txid\":\"the_txid\",\"vout\":1,\"scriptPubKey\":\"bladiebla\",\"redeemScript\":\"37898ew7er98adjf\"}] ["privatekey"])`

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and put the "[...]" arrays inside quotes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and \" inside the array

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: for the privatekey also

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: sometimes it is easier to just use curl to submit

Author: bartwr#6773
Content: `komodo-cli.exe signrawtransaction "hexstring" "[{\"txid\":\"the_txid\",\"vout\":1,\"scriptPubKey\":\"bladiebla\",\"redeemScript\":\"37898ew7er98adjf\"}]" "[\"privatekey\"]"`

Author: bartwr#6773
Content: Whoo, seems to work indeed!

Author: bartwr#6773
Content: Thank you very much, jl. Took a while, was difficult to debug. Now this ^ works on Windows indeed. I will remember the fact that curl is sometimes easier to work with.

Author: ttt#3928
Content: Is it possible to have a separated chain for smart contracts?

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: yes each chain decides if cryptoconditions are active or not

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and each independent chain runs CC contracts independently, since each chain is independent

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the only exceptions would be cross chain contracts that use tx from other chains as input to their local contracts

Author: ttt#3928
Content: so it's depend from -ac_cc config flag?

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: This is the network cluster on which the chain can interact with other chains via cross chain smart contracts. This functionality is still in testing. If this is set to 1, the chain will have smart contracts enabled, but it will not be able to interact with other chains. If this is set to any number other than 0 or 1, the chain can interact with other chains on the same network cluster. For example, all -ac_cc=2 chains can interact with each other but may not interact with -ac_cc=3 chains. If you‚Äôd like to explicitly disable smart contracts set this value to 0.

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: komodo-platform.readthedocs.io/en/latest/komodo/assetchain-params.html

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: for MoMoM

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is for fungible chains, it is actually 101+ in the latest

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so ccid >1 && ccid < 101 are clusters that can validate each other's transactions, but they are not fungible
